Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of an Augmented Reality-Based Portable Navigation System for Acetabular Cup Placement in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 46 patients scheduled for THA were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: The study setting and participant eligibility criteria were not specified.

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to either the AR navigation group or the conventional group

Objective.evidence: This study investigates the efficacy of an augmented reality (AR)-based portable navigation system in improving the accuracy of acetabular component placement during total hip arthroplasty (THA) compared to the conventional freehand technique.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the absolute difference between the targeted and postoperative measured placement angles

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 46 patients scheduled for THA were randomly assigned

Result_Outcome.evidence: The AR navigation group demonstrated smaller mean differences in radiographic inclination compared to the conventional group (2.3° ± 1.4° vs. 3.9° ± 2.4°; p = 0.009) and in CT images (1.9° ± 1.3° vs. 3.4° ± 2.6°; p = 0.02).

Harms.evidence: No complications were associated with the use of the AR system.
